June 23, 2013: Fiction
INFERNO, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday.) The symbologist Robert Langdon, on the run
in Florence, must decipher a series of codes created by a Dante-loving scientist.
AND THE MOUNTAINS ECHOED, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead.) A
multigenerational family saga centers on a brother and sister born in Afghanistan; from
the author of “The Kite Runner.”
REVENGE WEARS PRADA, by Lauren Weisberger. (Simon & Schuster.) Andrea
Sachs is now running a bridal magazine.
THE KILL ROOM, by Jeffery Deaver. (Grand Central.) The quadriplegic forensics
expert Lincoln Rhyme investigates the political assassination of a United States citizen.
LADIES' NIGHT, by Mary Kay Andrews. (St. Martin's.) After separating from her
husband, a lifestyle blogger moves in with her mother and attends divorce counseling
sessions.
ZERO HOUR, by Clive Cussler and Graham Brown. (Putnam.) Kurt Austin, Joe Zavala
and the rest of the Numa team search for a physicist's machine, buried in an ocean
trench, that can cause deadly earthquakes in the 11th Numa Files novel.
DEEPLY ODD, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam.) Odd Thomas, who can communicate with
the dead, must forestall a crime by discovering the people who have been targeted by
a killer.
THE HIT, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central.) The government hitman Will Robie
uncovers a serious threat as he attempts to take out a fellow assassin who has gone
rogue.
SILKEN PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam.) Lucas Davenport is drawn into the
investigation of a Minnesota political scandal and the disappearance of an operative.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown.) A woman disappears on her fifth anniversary;
is her husband a killer?
A DANCE WITH DRAGONS, by George R. R. Martin. (Bantam.) Book 5 of "A Song of
Ice and Fire."
THE SON, by Philipp Meyer. (Ecco/HarperCollins.) More than 150 years in a Texas
family, from Comanche raids to the present, and its rise to money and power in the
cattle and oil industries.
TRANSATLANTIC, by Colum McCann. (Random House.) The lives of real and fictional
characters (Frederick Douglass, George Mitchell, an Irish maid) are woven into
historical events in Dublin, Newfoundland and New York.
12TH OF NEVER, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown.) One week
Non-Fiction
HAPPY, HAPPY, HAPPY, by Phil Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard
Books.) The Duck Commander pays tribute to “faith, family and ducks.”
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf.) The chief operating
officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.
AMERICAN GUN, by Chris Kyle with William Doyle. (Morrow/HarperCollins.) Kyle,
a former member of the Navy SEALs who was shot to death in Texas in February,
tells how 10 firearms changed United States history.
THE GUNS AT LAST LIGHT, by Rick Atkinson. (Holt.) The final volume of the
Liberation Trilogy describes the Allied victory in Europe, from D-Day to the
German surrender.
ELEVEN RINGS, by Phil Jackson and Hugh Delehanty. (Penguin Press.) An
autobiography by the successful coach, who led his teams to 11 N.B.A.
championships.
LET'S EXPLORE DIABETES WITH OWLS, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown.)
Essays from the humorist on subjects like French dentistry and a North Carolina
Costco.
DAD IS FAT, by Jim Gaffigan. (Crown Archetype.) Life with five kids in a two-
bedroom New York City apartment.
KEEP IT PITHY, by Bill O'Reilly. (Crown Archetype.) A “highlight reel” of previous
writings, updated, from the host of “The O’Reilly Factor.”
THE DUCK COMMANDER FAMILY, by Willie and Korie Robertson with Mark
Schlabach. (Howard Books.) Behind the scenes at the A&E show “Duck Dynasty.”
REVOLUTIONARY SUMMER, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf.) This account of the
fateful summer of 1776 weaves the political (Continental Congress) and the
military (Continental Army).
THE UNWINDING, by George Packer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux.) The collapse of
American institutions, politics and culture and their replacement by organized
money, told through the stories of ordinary people and significant figures.
THE BOYS IN THE BOAT, by Daniel James Brown. (Viking.) The University of
Washington’s eight-oar crew and their quest for gold at the 1936 Berlin Olympics.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House.) An Olympic runner’s story
of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
THE TAO OF MARTHA, by Jen Lancaster. (New American Library.) A Martha
Stewart-inspired self-improvement quest.
